articles.headline: Oil Hits New High as Dow Flirts With Bear Territory
articles.snippet: Oil prices climbed further Friday and the Dow fell to as much as 20 percent below its high in October 2007 before pulling back in afternoon trading.
articles.abstract: Oil prices climbed further Friday and the Dow fell to as much as 20 percent below its high in October 2007 before pulling back in afternoon trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bear peeked out of its cave on Friday.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: Travelers Face Deep Flight Cuts by Summer’s End
articles.snippet: Analysts say cuts by the airlines will reduce U.S. flights this year by almost 10 percent, with deeper cuts in store.
articles.abstract: Analysts say cuts by the airlines will reduce U.S. flights this year by almost 10 percent, with deeper cuts in store.
articles.lead_paragraph: With summer barely under way, it may seem too early for travelers to start thinking about Labor Day. But that is when significant cuts in the airlines’ fleets and schedules will begin taking effect, making for a particularly jarring end to summer.

articles.headline: Nice Spot to Eat After Golf, but Women Are Barred
articles.snippet: The Phoenix Country Club’s policy of forbidding women in a center of power dining has resulted in a bitter dispute.
articles.abstract: The Phoenix Country Club’s policy of forbidding women in a center of power dining has resulted in a bitter dispute.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX  When the men of the Phoenix Country Club saw their feeding ways in peril, they did not tarry. Some sent nasty e-mail messages, hectored players on the fairway and, for good measure, urinated on a fellow club member’s pecan tree.

articles.headline: Venture Investors Wrap Up an Unusually Bleak Quarter
articles.snippet: Not a single company backed by venture capitalists has gone public this quarter, a result of the weaknesses in the financial markets.
articles.abstract: Not a single company backed by venture capitalists has gone public this quarter, a result of the weaknesses in the financial markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  So far this has been a challenging year for companies hoping to go public. But it has been even rougher on venture capitalists who were hoping to get a big payday from such an offering.

articles.headline: A Candidate Runs to a G.O.P. Chorus of ‘Don’t’
articles.snippet: Bob Barr, a Republican turned Libertarian, hopes to follow in the third-party footsteps of Ross Perot and Ralph Nader.
articles.abstract: Bob Barr, a Republican turned Libertarian, hopes to follow in the third-party footsteps of Ross Perot and Ralph Nader.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA  He has been called a spoiler. A would-be Ralph Nader. A thorn in the side of Senator John McCain and the Republican establishment.

articles.headline: Battered by Oil, Dow Touches Bear Territory
articles.snippet: The Dow briefly fell 20 percent below its October peak, the figure that is regarded as the start of a bear market.
articles.abstract: The Dow briefly fell 20 percent below its October peak, the figure that is regarded as the start of a bear market.
articles.lead_paragraph: After eight brutal months on Wall Street, the Dow Jones industrial average finally made it official: Blue-chip stocks have stumbled into bear territory.

articles.headline: Easy Target, but Not the Right One
articles.snippet: The Congressional hearings this week over the impact of speculators on the price of oil made for wonderful theater — but they had nothing to do with oil.
articles.abstract: The Congressional hearings this week over the impact of speculators on the price of oil made for wonderful theater — but they had nothing to do with oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: So now we know: it’s all the fault of those damnable speculators. They’re the ones to blame as the price of oil tops $140 a barrel.

articles.headline: Food-Shopping Tips Direct From the Store Manager
articles.snippet: As food costs soar, a high-quality grocer is experimenting with ways to save money while not sacrificing taste.
articles.abstract: As food costs soar, a high-quality grocer is experimenting with ways to save money while not sacrificing taste.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the bottom of some of its receipts, Heinen’s Fine Foods prints its phone number and asks customers to call in with comments. And each week, Tom Heinen, who runs the 17-store chain in the Cleveland area with his twin brother, Jeff, listens to a recording of those calls as he drives to work in his Chevy Blazer.

articles.headline: Taliban Imperil Pakistani City, a Major Hub
articles.snippet: The threat to Peshawar is a sign of the rising danger that the Taliban militants present to the entire region.
articles.abstract: The threat to Peshawar is a sign of the rising danger that the Taliban militants present to the entire region.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  In the last two months, Taliban militants have suddenly tightened the noose on this city of three million people, one of Pakistan’s biggest, establishing bases in surrounding towns and, in daylight, abducting residents for high ransoms.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Pir Zubair Shah

articles.headline: Zimbabwe Faces Wider Sanctions Under Bush Plan
articles.snippet: After Zimbabwe’s widely denounced presidential runoff, President Bush announced new steps aimed at what he called an “illegitimate government.”
articles.abstract: After Zimbabwe’s widely denounced presidential runoff, President Bush announced new steps aimed at what he called an “illegitimate government.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Bush called Saturday for an international arms embargo against Zimbabwe in the wake of last week’s “sham election,” and announced that the United States is drafting new economic sanctions that, for the first time, would take aim at the entire government of President Robert Mugabe.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Celia W. Dugger

articles.headline: E-Mail That Investors Might Like to Read
articles.snippet: E-mails attached to the Massachusetts complaint against UBS accusing it of defrauding investors support accusations in stunning black and white.
articles.abstract: E-mails attached to the Massachusetts complaint against UBS accusing it of defrauding investors support accusations in stunning black and white.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERY few years, the conflicts of interest so deeply embedded in the Wall Street business model emerge from the shadows for all to see. Coming to light last week, courtesy of Massachusetts regulators, was UBS’s dual roles in the auction-rate securities market, which have had devastating effects on the people and institutions that invested in them.

articles.headline: Weighing the Costs of a CT Scan’s Look Inside the Heart
articles.snippet: Driven by financial incentives, many doctors are adopting CT scans, but there is scant evidence they benefit most patients.
articles.abstract: Driven by financial incentives, many doctors are adopting CT scans, but there is scant evidence they benefit most patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: A group of cardiologists recently had a proposition for Dr. Andrew Rosenblatt, who runs a busy heart clinic in San Francisco: Would he join them in buying a CT scanner, a $1 million machine that produces detailed images of the heart?
articles.byline: By Alex Berenson and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: Political Freelancers Use Web to Join the Attack
articles.snippet: In the 2008 election, the most attention-grabbing attacks are often coming from people outside professional politics.
articles.abstract: In the 2008 election, the most attention-grabbing attacks are often coming from people outside professional politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif.  The video blasted across the Internet, drawing political blood from Senator John McCain within a matter of days.

articles.headline: 101 Secrets (and 9 Lives) of a Magazine Star
articles.snippet: After years of raising the profiles and circulations of magazines like Us Weekly and Star by emphasizing celebrity news and gossip, Bonnie Fuller is going out on her own.
articles.abstract: After years of raising the profiles and circulations of magazines like Us Weekly and Star by emphasizing celebrity news and gossip, Bonnie Fuller is going out on her own.
articles.lead_paragraph: WALK by the magazine rack, turn on a television at dinnertime or sneak a peek at the gossip sites during work, and you will notice a lot of Angelina and a ton of Paris, and see far too much of Britney. But in all of those places, there is someone who is more ubiquitous, more oddly present, than all those women combined.

articles.headline: Would You Hire Your Husband?
articles.snippet: Although women in general still struggle for pay parity, more women are running their own companies — and some are employing their husbands.
articles.abstract: Although women in general still struggle for pay parity, more women are running their own companies — and some are employing their husbands.
articles.lead_paragraph: NINE years ago, Laura Udall noticed that her young daughter Rachel suffered back pain from lugging her books back and forth to school. Ms. Udall, a former saleswoman at AT&T, decided to develop and market a backpack light enough for children to wear safely.

articles.headline: U.S. Advised Iraqi Ministry on Oil Deals
articles.snippet: The disclosure, on the eve of the contracts’ announcement, is the first confirmation of direct American involvement in deals to open Iraq’s oil to commercial development.
articles.abstract: The disclosure, on the eve of the contracts’ announcement, is the first confirmation of direct American involvement in deals to open Iraq’s oil to commercial development.
articles.lead_paragraph: A group of American advisers led by a small State Department team played an integral part in drawing up contracts between the Iraqi government and five major Western oil companies to develop some of the largest fields in Iraq, American officials say.

articles.headline: Falling Prices Grip Major Stock Markets Around the World
articles.snippet: As the United States markets edge toward bear territory, losing nearly 20 percent of their value from last fall’s peak, investors might wonder where they can turn for relief.
articles.abstract: As the United States markets edge toward bear territory, losing nearly 20 percent of their value from last fall’s peak, investors might wonder where they can turn for relief.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  As the United States markets edge toward bear territory, losing nearly 20 percent of their value from last fall’s peak, investors might wonder where they can turn for relief.

articles.headline: Little Movies, Big Problems
articles.snippet: Once you start looking under the tent poles, perhaps for a film where nothing is blown up, movie box office numbers become grim.
articles.abstract: Once you start looking under the tent poles, perhaps for a film where nothing is blown up, movie box office numbers become grim.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hollywood is having a good-to-great summer. Box office is marginally up  mostly on the strength of increased ticket prices, but still, there’s over $4.52 billion already in the bank this year, according to Media by Numbers. The big studios  the sworn enemy of moviegoing snobs  have used great casting, like Robert Downey Jr. in “Iron Man,” Steve Carell in “Get Smart,” filmmaking innovation in Pixar’s “Wall-E” and “Wanted” and smart retreading in “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull” and “Sex and the City” to leave both audiences and the people in the studio corner office happy.

articles.headline: Intel’s Dominance Is Challenged by a Low-Power Upstart
articles.snippet: Intel might do well to be alarmed by the computer chips being designed by Qualcomm, a maker of chips for cellphones.
articles.abstract: Intel might do well to be alarmed by the computer chips being designed by Qualcomm, a maker of chips for cellphones.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO  From mainframes to minicomputers and then PCs, each new computing generation has displaced its predecessor by reaching a broader audience and costing far less. And each time, the dominant company in one generation loses control in the next.

articles.headline: Google and Creator of ‘Family Guy’ Strike a Deal
articles.snippet: Google will syndicate a new animation series using its AdSense advertising system to Web sites that are predetermined to be gathering spots for the show’s target audience.
articles.abstract: Google will syndicate a new animation series using its AdSense advertising system to Web sites that are predetermined to be gathering spots for the show’s target audience.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Google is experimenting with a new method of distributing original material on the Web, and some Hollywood film financiers are betting millions that the company will succeed.

articles.headline: Veterans Long to Reclaim the Name ‘Swift Boat’
articles.snippet: When they talk about Swift boats, veterans recall friends killed, not the new synonym for a nasty campaign smear.
articles.abstract: When they talk about Swift boats, veterans recall friends killed, not the new synonym for a nasty campaign smear.
articles.lead_paragraph: Years ago, when William Miller talked about being in the Vietnam War  if he talked about being in the Vietnam War  he would tell people he served on a Swift boat.

articles.headline: Solution, or Mess? A Milk Jug for a Green Earth
articles.snippet: A simple change to the design of the gallon milk jug keeps the milk fresher and holds costs down.
articles.abstract: A simple change to the design of the gallon milk jug keeps the milk fresher and holds costs down.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH CANTON, Ohio  A simple change to the design of the gallon milk jug, adopted by Wal-Mart and Costco, seems made for the times. The jugs are cheaper to ship and better for the environment, the milk is fresher when it arrives in stores, and it costs less.

articles.headline: Hoarding Nations Drive Food Costs Ever Higher
articles.snippet: After at least 29 countries sharply curbed their food exports, impoverished importing countries are finding it more difficult to afford the food they need.
articles.abstract: After at least 29 countries sharply curbed their food exports, impoverished importing countries are finding it more difficult to afford the food they need.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK  At least 29 countries have sharply curbed food exports in recent months, to ensure that their own people have enough to eat, at affordable prices.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: Obama Camp Thinks Democrats Can Rise in South
articles.snippet: Barack Obama’s strategy relies on black turnout in a region that has bedeviled Democrats for 40 years.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama’s strategy relies on black turnout in a region that has bedeviled Democrats for 40 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As they look to the fall election, Democrats face a strategic decision that has bedeviled their party for 40 years: How hard should they fight in the South?

articles.headline: Don’t Forget the Middle People
articles.snippet: The Screen Actors Guild, now embroiled in negotiations with film and television producers over a new contract, has made the plight of the middle-income actor the centerpiece of its campaign for more lucrative terms.
articles.abstract: The Screen Actors Guild, now embroiled in negotiations with film and television producers over a new contract, has made the plight of the middle-income actor the centerpiece of its campaign for more lucrative terms.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  From his break in 1992 playing Bank Nerd No. 2 in the sitcom “Married With Children,” to his supporting role on the HBO hit “Six Feet Under,” to a part in last year’s “Spider-Man 3,” Tim Maculan has navigated Hollywood more successfully than most actors.
